item.title: Best Pokémon TCG Pocket Asleep Deck
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/best-pokemon-tcg-pocket-asleep-deck/

The best Asleep deck in Pokémon TCG Pocket is not only fun, but it’s useful for completing certain Battle Tasks. Having a top-end Asleep deck is a vital part of your Pokémon portfolio, and I have the perfect team you need to build.

Pokémon TCG Pocket has been a revelation. The older TCG app feels like a distant memory already, and Pocket’s future is looking brighter than a Flash HM. Future expansion details sound promising, and Pokémon TCG Pocket keeps dropping exciting events to bolster the wealth of content.

Most players already have a slew of dastardly decks designed to win battles in only a few turns. Our best Electric deck is the perfect example of this, but don’t sit around daydreaming when there’s a boss Asleep deck to assemble.

Best Asleep Deck in Pokémon TCG Pocket

Pokémon TCG Pocket’s best Asleep deck requires two copies each of Drowzee, Hypno, Snom, Frosmoth, Jigglypuff, and Wigglytuff EX.

The only downside to this deck is it mixes Grass, Water, and Psychic Energy—but it’s not the end of the world. Most Pokémon cards in this deck have moves featuring Colorless Energy anyway.

In terms of its strengths, you have multiple Pokémon here capable of inflicting Asleep. Another huge benefit to our Asleep deck is no Stage 3’s are required. There’s a high likelihood your first draw—along with a Poké Ball or Professor’s Research—can get you up and running immediately.

Furthermore, no one’s sleep move costs more than three energy, and the focus is on Wigglytuff EX—these are the cards we want. Its Sleepy Song move costs three Colorless Energy, does 80 Damage, and guarantees your opponent falls Asleep. Prioritize Jigglypuffs and Wigglytuff EXs, if you can.

Here’s our best Asleep deck in full.

Best Asleep Alternatives in Pokémon TCG Pocket

The evolution line of Oddish, Gloom, and Vileplume is the only other serious consideration for the best Asleep deck in Pokémon TCG Pocket.

Its omission from the main deck is the result of one aspect: It’s a three-stage evolution.

Meaning, you need a lot more luck on your side to get and use Vileplume. If you do, it’s one of the strongest Stage 3 cards in all of Pokémon TCG Pocket—primarily because it deals a lot of damage, puts Pokémon to sleep, and has 140 HP (unreal for a non-EX card.)

Why is Asleep Deck so Powerful in Pokémon TCG Pocket?

A lot of Pokémon TCG Pocket decks boil down to coin flips—and putting your opponent’s Mon to sleep can ruin entire game plans in the first few turns. It renders Pokémon catatonic, stops them from doing damage, and gives you free hits for as long as the coin flips are on your side.

Plus, in the case of the Venusaur Drop Event, certain Tasks and Rewards are tied to the Asleep condition. The aforementioned event features a Battle Task instructing players to “Make your opponent’s Pokémon Asleep 1 time.” So, even if you’re not concentrating on winning, this deck is sure to put someone to sleep.

Marvel Rivals is the definition of great power coming with great responsibility: It is a blockbuster shooter with a lot of star power but also requires enough firepower to sustain itself. This is where the Marvel Rivals System Requirements need to rise to the occasion, so let’s see if you meet the criteria.

Throughout the Marvel Rivals alpha and beta tests, it became apparent the hero shooter is a good-looking game. Its cel-shaded visuals pop and every attack pulsates with a rich palette of colors and effects. Marvel Rivals is easy on the eyes, but players wonder if it’s as forgiving on hardware.

NetEase Games wants as many people playing Marvel Rivals as possible, and having higher system requirements can be costly.

Marvel Rivals Minimum Requirements on PC

The minimum requirements for Marvel Rivals are designed to be as inclusive as possible. While a low-end rig is probably not going to cut it, I’ve definitely seen worse figures where minimum requirements are concerned. I experienced some issues during the alpha test with a good system, but this is probably a thing of the past now.

Marvel Rivals should play just fine if you have decent RAM and a solid processor. It’s also recommended you install the game on an SSD drive for an improved experience.
